The force of gravity between two objects depends on their masses and the distance between them, increasing as the product of their masses and decreasing with the square of the distance between their centers. 

On Earth, gravity gives weight to physical objects and causes them to fall when dropped. It keeps planets in orbit around the sun and influences the movements of celestial bodies. Gravity is also responsible for the shape, size, and tides of our oceans. The force of gravity is essential to our understanding of the universe and has been pivotal in the development of physics and astronomy.

Gravity is one of the four fundamental forces that govern physical interactions, the others being electromagnetism and the strong and weak nuclear forces. It is a force that causes mutual attraction between all things with mass or energy. The force of gravity between two objects depends on their masses and the distance between them. 

The most familiar effect of gravity is the weight of physical objects. For example, the weight of a book is the force of gravity acting on it, which pulls it downwards. Gravity also governs the motions of celestial bodies, such as the orbits of planets around the sun and the moon around the earth. On Earth, gravity gives inertia to everything, keeping us grounded and governing the tides.

Gravity is one of the four fundamental forces that govern the universe and is the force that gives mass and energy to everything in the universe. It is an attractive force that exists between all things with mass or energy, pulling them together. It is what makes things fall to the ground and holds celestial bodies in orbit. Gravity is relatively weak compared to the other fundamental forces—the strong and weak nuclear forces and electromagnetism—but it is the most prevalent force in the universe because it affects all matter. Its influence determines the motion of galaxies, stars, planets, and everything on Earth, including us!

The strength of gravity depends on the amount of mass and energy involved. For example, the gravitational pull of a black hole is much stronger than that of a small rock.
